act:act.act:conveniencehead: [This is an unofficial consolidation prepared August 24, 2016 for convenience only.]
act:act.act:title: Community Charter Transitional Provisions, Consequential Amendments and Other Amendments Act, 2003

bcl:text.#text: means a bylaw that is validly in force on the day before the date that the authority for the bylaw is repealed, amended or substituted by this Act or the ;
, in relation to an enactment, means, as applicable,
the relevant provision of the , or

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the enactment as amended or substituted by the relevant provision of this Act;

bcl:text.#text: , in relation to an enactment, means the provision as it read immediately before its repeal, amendment or substitution by the applicable provision of this Act or the .

bcl:section.bcl:text: Despite the amendment, substitution or repeal of a previous enactment, if this Part or a regulation under this Part provides for the continued application, or the continuation, of bylaws authorized under the previous enactment, the previous enactment is deemed to be continued for this purpose.

bcl:text.#text: Despite this Act, the  or any other Act, the Lieutenant Governor in Council may make regulations as follows:
respecting any matter that the Lieutenant Governor in Council considers is not provided for, or is not sufficiently provided for, in the , this Act or another Act affected by the  or this Act;
making provisions the Lieutenant Governor in Council considers necessary or advisable for the purpose of more effectively bringing the  or this Act into operation;

making provisions the Lieutenant Governor in Council considers necessary or advisable for the purpose of preventing, minimizing or otherwise addressing any transitional difficulties encountered in bringing into operation the , this Act or another Act affected by the  or this Act, including provisions providing an exception to or a modification of a provision in an Act or providing for the continued application of a previous enactment;
resolving any errors, inconsistencies or ambiguities in the , this Act or another Act that arise in relation to the  or this Act.
A regulation under subsection (1) may be made retroactive to a date not earlier than March 11, 2003, being the date on which the  received First Reading in the Legislative Assembly.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: To the extent of any conflict between a regulation under subsection (1) and another enactment, the regulation prevails.
A regulation under subsection (1) ceases to have effect at the end of the last day of the next session of the Legislative Assembly after the regulation is made.
A regulation may not be made under subsection (1) if a regulation has been made under that subsection that has the same effect.
Regulations may not be made under subsection (1) after December 31, 2005.

If a previous enactment provided authority for an existing bylaw that could not be adopted under a new enactment, the bylaw continues in force as a valid bylaw until it is repealed or amended, unless the amendment is adopted after a regulation under subsection (2) has continued the necessary authority.

If a bylaw is continued under subsection (1), a local government that intends to amend the bylaw may request that the Lieutenant Governor in Council, by regulation, continue the authority necessary in relation to the bylaw and the Lieutenant Governor in Council may make regulations for that purpose.
A regulation under subsection (2) may be made retroactive to the date on which the enactment that provided authority was repealed, amended or substituted.
If an existing bylaw has new authority, the bylaw

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: is deemed to have been adopted under that authority, and

bcl:text.#text: in the case of a bylaw to which section 9  of the  would apply if the bylaw were adopted after that section came into force, is deemed to have been adopted with the approval of the minister responsible.
Section 8 (9) of the  does not apply in respect of a bylaw deemed under section 4 (4) of this Act to have been adopted under section 8 (3), (4), (5) or (6) of the , unless the council

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: amends the bylaw in a manner that requires the exercise of a power under section 8 (3), (4), (5) or (6) of that Act to regulate, prohibit or impose requirements, or

bcl:text.#text: If a previous enactment required that a counter petition opportunity be provided in relation to a bylaw or other matter, and if notice of the counter petition opportunity has been given in accordance with the previous section 172.4  of the ,

the rules under the  respecting a counter petition opportunity continue to apply so long as the bylaw is adopted or the relevant action is taken, as applicable, within one year after the requirement for a counter petition is repealed, and

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the provisions of the new enactment respecting approval of the electors do not apply.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A bylaw adopted or another action taken under a previous enactment following a counter petition opportunity is deemed to have been adopted with the approval of the electors.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Hazard and nuisance requirements in process

bcl:text.#text: If, before Division 12  of Part 3 of the  comes into force,

bcl:text: the local government may proceed under the previous enactment and, if so, the previous enactment continues to apply.

bcl:text.#text: a bylaw under the previous section 698  or 711  of the  has been given first reading, or
a resolution under the previous section 727  of the  has been adopted,

in:desc: [mayor may require reconsideration of a matter]
[mayor may return bylaw for reconsideration by council]
bcl:text.#text: If a bylaw, resolution or proceeding was voted on by a local government before section 131  of the  came into force, the mayor or chair may require reconsideration of the matter only in accordance with the previous section 219  of the , and for these purposes section 219 of that Act applies.

in:desc: [works that may be undertaken as local improvements]
bcl:text.#text: If the construction under a construction bylaw adopted under the previous section 623  or 624  of the  is started or completed by, or will be started within one year of, the date that the previous Part 19  of the  is repealed, the previous Division 1  of Part 19 of the  continues to apply in relation to that construction.

in:desc: [payment of costs from local improvement fund]
bcl:text.#text: As an exception to section 189  of the , the previous section 639  of the  continues to apply for the purposes of the application of the previous Division 1  of Part 19 of the  in relation to a construction bylaw referred to in subsection (1).

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Heritage, riparian, cemetery and golf course exemptions and valuations

in:desc: [repayment requirement in relation to heritage tax exemptions]
bcl:text.#text: In relation to a tax exemption provided under the previous section 342  of the , the previous section 343  of that Act continues to apply.

in:desc: [repayment requirement in relation to riparian exemptions]
bcl:text.#text: In relation to a tax exemption provided under the previous section 343.1  of the , the previous section 343.2  of that Act continues to apply.
In relation to a valuation agreement under the previous Division 2  of Part 10 of the , that previous Division continues to apply until the valuation agreement expires.

bcl:text.in:desc: [further liability for 10 years after end of valuation agreement]
bcl:text.#text: In addition to its application under subsection (3), the previous Division 2 of Part 10 of the  continues to apply after the expiration of a valuation agreement as provided in the previous section 350  of that Act.

If a bylaw referred to in the previous section 553  of the  has overridden the terms of any agreement respecting the carriage or supply of water for irrigation, the previous section 553 continues to apply in respect of the agreement.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Disposal of assets acquired with Provincial grants

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: This section applies only in relation to grants provided by the Provincial government before this section comes into force.

bcl:text.#text: As a limitation on section 8 (1)  of the  and section 176 (1) (d)  of the , unless excepted under subsection (3) of this section, a local government must notify the inspector before disposing of land, improvements or works acquired or constructed by or for a local government in whole or in part with a Provincial grant that was provided for that purpose.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The obligation to notify the inspector under subsection (2) does not apply if

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the first payment of all or part of the grant was provided at least 20 years before the intended disposal and the local government no longer receives grant payments with respect to that property, or
the land, improvement or work will be used for the public purpose for which it was acquired or constructed for at least 20 years after the date of the first payment of all or part of the grant.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Within 30 days after receiving notice under subsection (2) or, if applicable, within the longer period established under subsection (6), the inspector may, subject to the regulations, by notice in writing require the local government to repay all or part of the Provincial grants paid to the local government with respect to the property, on the terms specified in the notice.

bcl:text.#text: The local government may appeal a decision of the inspector under subsection (4) of this section and, for this purpose, the new section 1024  of the  applies.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The Lieutenant Governor in Council may make regulations for the purposes of this section as follows:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: respecting the matters or information to be included in the local government's notification to the inspector;
prescribing the conditions under which a grant becomes repayable under this section;
respecting the means and basis for calculating the whole or part of the Provincial grant that is repayable;
specifying the circumstances in which the inspector may take more than 30 days to issue a notice under subsection (4).

bcl:text.#text: The vesting of Crown land in a municipality under section 29  of the  that occurs on the date that section comes into force is subject to any reservations that applied to the Crown's title.
For the first annual report required under section 98  of the , the following do not apply:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the obligations under subsection (2) (b), (c) and (d) of that section;
the obligation under subsection (2) (f) of that section to include a statement of objectives for the current year;
the obligation under subsection (2) (f) of that section to include measures that will be used to determine progress respecting objectives for the current and next year.

bcl:text.#text: For the second annual report required under section 98 of the , the obligations under subsection (2) (d) of that section do not apply.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Disclosure of gifts and personal benefits

bcl:text.#text: Section 106 (2)  of the  does not apply in respect of any gift or benefit received before the date that section comes into force.
The obligation to adopt a procedure bylaw respecting the matters referred to in section 124 (2)  of the  does not apply until 120 days after that section comes into force.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Until a procedure bylaw respecting the matters referred to in subsection (1) of this section is adopted,

in:desc: [procedure bylaws — council and council committee minutes]
bcl:text.#text: for the purposes of section 124 (2) (c)  of the , the previous sections 236  and 237  of the  apply,
for the purposes of section 124 (2) (e)  of the , the municipal hall is deemed to be the public notice posting place, and

bcl:text.in:desc: [council members to choose member to preside]
bcl:text.#text: section 130 (2)  of the  applies whenever the mayor is absent from a council meeting.

A sinking fund to which the previous Division 1  of Part 13 of the  applied and that is in existence at the time that Division is repealed, continues as a sinking fund and, for that purpose, that Division continues to apply until the debt for which the sinking fund was established is paid.
A debt retirement fund under the previous Division 2  of Part 13 of the  that is in existence at the time that Division is repealed is deemed to be a reserve fund under Division 4  of Part 6 of the .
A reserve fund established for the purposes of the previous section 935  of the  is deemed to be a reserve fund under Division 4  of Part 6 of the .
A local improvement fund under the previous section 500  of the  is deemed to be a reserve fund established under Division 4  of Part 6 of the .
If, at the time Division 4  of Part 7 of the  comes into force,

the parcel tax is imposed on that parcel for the calendar year in which section 201 of the  comes into force, but does not apply to the parcel for subsequent years unless circumstances change such that the parcel has the opportunity to be provided with the service.
a bylaw under the previous Division 2  of Part 10.1 of the  imposes a parcel tax in relation to a service that is provided to land or improvements,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the bylaw imposes the parcel tax for more than one year, and

bcl:text.#text: the parcel tax is imposed on a parcel that does not have the opportunity to be provided with the service as required under section 201 (2)  of the ,

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Specified areas and business improvement areas

bcl:text.#text: Specified areas under the previous Part 19  of the  are deemed to be local service areas under Division 5  of Part 7 of the .
Business improvement areas and mountain resort business improvement areas under the previous Part 19  of the  are deemed to be business improvement areas under section 215  of the .
The new section 6.6 (3)  of the  applies to regulations under this Act.

bcl:part.bcl:text: Other Amendments to the Community Charter

bcl:editorialnote.in:em: [Note: See Table of Legislative Changes for the status of these Acts.]

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Subject to subsections (2) to (9), this Act comes into force by regulation of the Lieutenant Governor in Council.
Sections 3 and 20 are deemed to have come into force on March 11, 2003 and are retroactive to the extent necessary to give them effect on and after that date.

bcl:text.#text: Section 39 comes into force on the day that section 205 of the , S.B.C. 2002, c. 57, comes into force.

bcl:link.in:doc: Community Care and Assisted Living Act

bcl:text.#text: Sections 41 (a) and 42 (b) come into force on the day that the , S.B.C. 2002, c. 75, comes into force.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Section 41 (b) comes into force on December 31, 2003 for the purposes of the 2004 and subsequent taxation years.

bcl:text.#text: Sections 83, 96 and 108 (a) come into force by regulation of the Lieutenant Governor in Council, which regulation may not be made before the date that sections 8, 12 and 14 of the , S.B.C. 2002, c. 48, come into force.

Section 163, as it relates to the definitions of "regional park" and "regional trail", comes into force on the day that the , R.S.B.C. 1996, c. 345, is repealed, and is retroactive to the extent necessary to have effect on and after that date.
Section 307 comes into force on the day that the , S.B.C. 2002, c. 77, comes into force.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The following sections are deemed to have come into force on February 19, 2003 and are retroactive to the extent necessary to give them effect on and after that date:

bcl:text.#text: section 265, as it enacts section 363.1 of the ;
section 498, as it enacts section 2.1 (2) of the  in relation to the application of section 193.1 of the .
